summary: James N. Roethe was a Commission staff member involved in taking depositions related to potential CIA involvement in assassination plots. He is mentioned in connection with the deposition of Frank Sturgis and Wilfredo Navarro on April 4, 1975, where they discussed potential CIA involvement in assassination plots. Roethe also authored a memorandum summarizing information obtained from George Brewer regarding the CIA's Washington Field Office activities. He is also mentioned in the transcript of Frank Sturgis' deposition on April 3, 1975, discussing Sturgis' involvement in potential assassination attempts on Fidel Castro and other Cuban officials, as well as his connections to the CIA and other intelligence activities. His involvement appears to be focused on gathering information and taking depositions related to CIA activities and potential assassination plots.
significance: James N. Roethe's significance in the JFK context lies in his role as a Commission staff member investigating potential CIA involvement in assassination plots, particularly those involving Fidel Castro and other Cuban officials. His work involved taking depositions from key figures like Frank Sturgis and gathering information about the CIA's activities.
